prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old to a fun activity while their partner is at work. The situation is that the author and partner have conflicts about weekend plans. The author says they usually suggest going to places like the play centre or a farm, but the partner gives excuses like being tired, not wanting to go, or not wanting to spend money, even though they have the money. This time, the author agreed to go to a farm with a friend's kids, and the partner got upset, saying it's unfair because he's at work. The author pointed out that they had tried before and been refused, and now the partner is upset.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. The user thinks the author is in the wrong. Let me consider both sides. 

First, the author's perspective: They tried to involve the partner in planning activities but were consistently met with excuses. The partner didn't participate, so the author took the initiative to make their child happy. The activity is a petting zoo, not a movie date, so it's not replacing the partner but giving the child an experience. The author is doing what's best for the child and themselves, given the partner's reluctance.

On the other hand, the partner might feel left out or not included in family activities. If the author usually goes out with the child, but when they can't involve the partner, maybe the partner feels it's unfair. However, in this case, the partner was busy at work, so maybe the author is justified in taking the child alone. The partner's reaction might be more about feeling excluded rather than the activity itself.

But the partner had previously declined the author's suggestions, so why is this different? The author is acting on the child's behalf, ensuring they get to enjoy something fun. The cost isn't an issue, and the partner is the one who didn't want to go before. The author's decision to go without the partner might be reasonable if it's for the child's benefit and the partner is unavailable. The partner might need to adjust their expectations about being involved in every activity.

So, considering all that, the author isn't in the wrong. They tried to include the partner but were rebuffed each time. Taking the child to a fun activity is a positive action, especially when the partner is at work. The partner's reaction seems more about feeling left out rather than a valid reason to cancel. Therefore, the answer is B (the author is not in the wrong).
